{{Primary sources|date=July 2008}}
[[Image:Live USB ubuntu.png|thumb|280px|right|A live USB of [[Ubuntu (operating system)|Ubuntu]], running [[Firefox]], [[OpenOffice.org]] and [[Nautilus (file manager)|Nautilus]].]]
[[Image:Live USB ubuntu.png|thumb|280px|right|A live USB of [[Ubuntu (operating system)|Ubuntu]], running [[Firefox]], [[OpenOffice.org]] and [[Nautilus (file manager)|Nautilus]].]]
â
A '''live USB''' is a [[USB flash drive]] or a USB [[external hard disk drive]] containing a full [[operating system]] which can be [[booting|booted]]. Live USBs are closely related to [[live CD]]s, but typically have the ability to save settings and permanently install software packages back onto the USB device. Like live CDs, live USBs can be used in embedded systems for [[system administration]], [[data recovery]], or the testing of operating system distributions without committing to a permanent installation on the local [[hard disk drive]]. Many operating systems including Microsoft [[Windows XP Embedded]] and many of the [[Linux distribution]]s and [[Berkeley Software Distribution|BSD]]s can also be used from a USB flash drive.
+
A '''live USB''' is a [[USB flash drive]] or a USB [[external hard disk drive]] containing a full [[operating system]] which can be [[booting|booted]]. Live USBs are closely related to [[live CD]]s, but sometimes have the ability to save settings and permanently install software packages back onto the USB device. Like live CDs, live USBs can be used in embedded systems for [[system administration]], [[data recovery]], or the testing of operating system distributions without committing to a permanent installation on the local [[hard disk drive]]. Many operating systems including Microsoft [[Windows XP Embedded]] and many of the [[Linux distribution]]s and [[Berkeley Software Distribution|BSD]]s can also be used from a USB flash drive.
